In Bologna, Italy, we propose a novel method for adjusting and post-processing grid-based rainfall data products. Our method utilizes a U-Net, a deep convolutional neural network, as its backbone, and a novel loss function that combines a pixel-wise bias component (Mean Absolute Error) and a spatial accuracy component (Fractions Skill Score). We evaluate the proposed approach by adjusting extreme rainfall from the ERA5 reanalysis dataset, using the multi-source observational dataset MSWEP as a target. We focus on a sample of extreme rainfall events induced by tropical cyclones and show that the proposed method significantly reduces both the MAE (by 16%) and FSS (by 53%) of ERA5.

Introduction

Tropical cyclones are one of the costliest and deadliest natural hazards due to their strong winds and induced storm surges and heavy precipitation, which can cause devastating floods. However, precipitation is still one of the most challenging aspects of a tropical cyclone to model due to its high spatio-temporal variability, complex underlying physical processes, and lack of high-quality observations. Accurate precipitation input is crucial for reliable hydrological simulations and forecasts, which can inform disaster risk management decisions. The ERA5 reanalysis dataset is a popular source of precipitation data, frequently used as input to hydrological models when studying floods. Previous studies have found that ERA5 systematically underestimates heavy precipitation events, particularly the spatial distribution of TC-rainfall in ERA5, which has room for improvement to accurately identify TC landfall and inform decisions.

We present a precipitation post-processing scheme based on U-Net, a popular deep-learning architecture. Originally developed in medical computer vision, U-Net is now widely used for applying transformations to gridded data without altering the input resolution. Our model not only adjusts the per-pixel precipitation values at each timestep of a given TC but also adjusts the spatial distribution of the precipitation. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to do so. The key novelty of our model is a custom-made loss function, based on the combination of the Fractions Skill Score (FSS) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) metrics.

We train and validate the model on over 200,000 time steps from global precipitation events induced by TCs. We show that a U-Net trained with our loss function can reduce the per-pixel MAE of ERA5 precipitation by nearly as much as a U-Net trained with only MAE as the loss function, while outperforming it significantly in terms of improved spatial patterns of precipitation.

Data and Methodology

Data

We downloaded the hourly global total precipitation fields of ERA5 from the Climate Data Store at a resolution of 0.25° x 0.25°, between 1980 and 2020. We also downloaded precipitation data over the same period for the MSWEP dataset, which we used as the gold standard in our study. As MSWEP comes with 3-hourly temporal and 0.1° x 0.1° spatial resolution, we regridded ERA5 onto MSWEP's grid using linear interpolation and aggregated it to a 3-hourly temporal resolution. We used the best-track data from the International Best Track Archive for Climate Stewardship (IBTrACS) project to locate TC centres, at a temporal resolution of 3h. For each timestep in IBTrACS, we cropped ERA5 and MSWEP around a 500 km-radius box centred on that TC.
